abstract: We study the intrinsic computational power of correlations exploited in measurement-based quantum computation. By defining a general framework, the meaning of the computational power of correlations is made precise. This leads to a notion of resource states for measurement-based classical computation. Surprisingly, the Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger and Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt problems emerge as optimal examples. Our work exposes an intriguing relationship between the violation of local realistic models and the computational power of entangled resource states.
